A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: ambivalence or even worse\, hostility toward the mythos along with the faithful fan base and a total embracing of moral relativism makes for a movie with no heroes\, no character development\, and little humanity. Beloved core characters are put out to pasture after learning nothing from their experiences in previous installments. I did not think it was possible to quell the love for a franchise with such a divisive stroke\, but those heading this film have force choked the identity of this beloved franchise and alienated its fanbase with such profundity\, star wars as a cultural stalwart may never recover. In itself it may not be a poor movie\, but in the series it somehow manages to bring destruction to the essence of star wars magic. A mythos cannot have the same power in every generation and yet star wars magic has spanned many. This is largely because each successive chapter honors it's predecessor while speaking in a the language of the current culture.  Johnson does not mean to honor the past and build a bridge. He means to burn it down. And to large degree\, he has.
